content.description: A good technical face climb up the middle of the cleanest section of wall. An obvious line with some not so obvious moves at the end. The rock is mostly good and the climbing interesting.
content.location: From the bright yellow wall, continue down the trail to the cliff base. A massive dihedral will be seen with a WIDE flaring crack going to the top. Public Option climbs up the middle of the left wall, following faint, left-angling dihedral features in the face. Scramble up 20 feet to a ledge where the climb begins.

content.description: Just right of Cam Wars and shares the same start. Climb big, wide, hollow, yellow layback flake to its end, then face climb the last 20 feet to the anchor. Beware of some stacked loose rocks off to the right at the finish.
content.location: Same start as Cam Wars on the bright yellow wall. Move right to the second bolt.

content.description: A crusty, lichenous, crack/flake system leads to a steep thin hands bulge at the end. Proud trad F.A. by David Bloom, however we decided that bolts would make it far more enjoyable.
content.location: First climb as you approach the cliff, located on the west facing, bright yellow wall. Starts up right angling crack, but heads back left, straight up the discontinuous flake/crack system. Finishes up the obvious steep hand crack in the last 15 feet.

content.description: The Fire Wall is an 80-120 foot south facing cliff perched high on Bill Williams Mountain. The rock is crusty and lichenous, but offers several long, visually pleasing lines. Because of the rugged mountain setting and exposure, the cliff feels wild, remote and adventurous, even though it's only 10 minutes from the car. Unfortunately, the rock quality at this wall is a little unsavory at times. The exposure and views, however, validate the climbing experience. A helmet is a good idea. Just a few routes to date, but more lines are possible.
